content: The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 may be cited as the Act. It includes provisions for higher maximum penalties for mail and wire fraud. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for mail, wire, and securities fraud. Mail and wire fraud penalties are raised from five to twenty years, while a new section on securities fraud is added to the United States Code. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for securities fraud, including fines or imprisonment up to 25 years for defrauding individuals in connection with securities registered under specific acts. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for securities fraud, with fines or imprisonment up to 25 years for violations under specific acts. The Corporate Fraud Accountability Act of 2002 increases penalties for securities fraud, with fines or imprisonment up to 25 years for violations under specific acts, including tampering with a record or impeding an official proceeding. Section 1512 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include penalties for corruptly altering, destroying, or obstructing records or official proceedings, with fines or imprisonment up to 20 years. The amendment to Section 1512 of title 18, United States Code includes penalties for obstructing official proceedings, with fines or imprisonment up to 20 years. Amendment to the Federal Sentencing Guidelines. Request for Immediate Consideration by The United States Sentencing Commission to review and enhance sentencing guidelines for securities and accounting fraud committed by officers or directors of publicly traded corporations. The United States Sentencing Commission is urged to promptly review and update sentencing guidelines for fraud committed by officers or directors of publicly traded corporations. This includes considering enhancements for such offenses and submitting policy recommendations to Congress. The Sentencing Commission is requested to review sentencing guidelines for securities, pension, and accounting fraud, ensuring they reflect the seriousness of these offenses and the need for aggressive law enforcement. They should also consider consistency with other directives and guidelines, and account for any circumstances that may justify exceptions. Commission must act promptly, within 120 days of enactment, following specified procedures. SEC. 5. DEBTS NONDISCHARGEABLE IF INCURRED IN VIOLATION OF SECURITIES FRAUD LAWS. Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, is amended to include a new paragraph (19) regarding claims for violations of federal securities laws, state securities laws, or related regulations. The amendment to Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, includes a new paragraph (19) covering claims for violations of federal securities laws, state securities laws, or related regulations, including common law fraud, deceit, or manipulation in connection with securities transactions. The amendment to Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, includes a new paragraph (19) covering claims related to violations of securities laws, including judgments, settlements, damages, fines, penalties, and restitutionary payments. The amendment to Section 523(a) of title 11, United States Code, includes a new paragraph (19) covering claims related to violations of securities laws, including court or administrative orders for payments owed by the debtor. SEC. 6. CORPORATE RESPONSIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL REPORTS. Sec. 1349 of Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code, requires corporate officers to certify financial reports filed with the Securities Exchange Commission. The certification must be provided by the chairman of the board, chief executive officer, and chief financial officer of the issuer. The certification required by Sec. 1349 of Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code, must be accompanied by a written statement from the chairman of the board, CEO, and CFO of the issuer. The statement certifies that the financial statements accurately represent the issuer's operations and financial condition. Violations of this section can result in criminal penalties of fines up to $1,000,000 or imprisonment up to 10 years for knowing violations, and fines up to $5,000,000 or imprisonment up to 20 years for willful violations. The penalties for violating Sec. 1349 of Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code include fines up to $1,000,000 or imprisonment up to 10 years for knowing violations, and fines up to $5,000,000 or imprisonment up to 20 years for willful violations. SEC. 7. ATTEMPTS AND CONSPIRACIES TO COMMIT CRIMINAL OFFENSES. Any person who attempts or conspires to commit any offense against the United States shall be subject to the same penalties as those prescribed for the offense. SEC. 8 increases criminal penalties under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, raising the maximum fine to $5,000,000 and maximum imprisonment to 20 years. SEC. 9 grants temporary freeze authority to the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include a temporary freeze provision for investigations involving possible violations of securities laws by publicly traded companies or their affiliates. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 allows the Commission to petition a Federal district court for a temporary order requiring an issuer to escrow funds if it is likely that the issuer will make extraordinary payments to certain individuals involved in possible violations of securities laws. The Commission can petition a Federal district court for a temporary order to escrow payments to individuals involved in possible securities law violations for 45 days, with court supervision. A temporary order can be entered after notice and a hearing, unless impracticable or contrary to public interest. The order becomes effective immediately and must be served on the parties involved. The temporary order issued under clause (i) becomes effective immediately, must be served on the parties involved, and remains enforceable for 45 days unless modified by a court. Extensions can be authorized by the court. The temporary order issued under clause (i) is enforceable for 45 days and can be extended by the court for up to an additional 45 days, not exceeding a total of 90 days, for violations charged against the issuer or other relevant parties. The temporary order issued can be extended for up to 90 days if violations are charged against the issuer or other relevant parties. The temporary order issued can be extended for up to 90 days if violations are charged against the issuer or other relevant parties, subject to court approval. The order remains in effect until the conclusion of legal proceedings, and the affected party can petition the court for review if no violations are charged. If no violations are charged before the temporary order expires, the escrow will end at the end of the 45-day effective period. The escrow will terminate at the end of the 45-day effective period, and disputed payments will be returned to the issuer. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. SEC. 10. AUTHORITY OF THE COMMISSION TO PROHIBIT PERSONS FROM SERVING AS OFFICERS OR DIRECTORS. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 allows the Commission to prohibit individuals who have violated certain regulations from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 empowers the Commission to bar individuals who have breached regulations from acting as officers or directors of registered issuers. The Commission may prohibit such individuals if their conduct demonstrates unsuitability for these roles. The Securities Act of 1933 allows the Commission to prohibit individuals who violate regulations from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers. This authority can be exercised in cease-and-desist proceedings for violations of section 17(a)(1) or related rules. The Securities Act of 1933 empowers the Commission to bar individuals who violate regulations from acting as officers or directors of registered issuers. This authority can be utilized in cease-and-desist proceedings for breaches of section 17(a)(1) or associated rules. SEC. 11. RETALIATION AGAINST INFORMANT. Amends Section 1513 of title 18, United States Code to penalize retaliation against informants providing truthful information to law enforcement regarding Federal offenses. Penalties include fines or up to 10 years imprisonment. Passed by the House of Representatives on July 16, 2002, attested by Jeff Trandahl, Clerk.
